G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Superior Court has subject-matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4 because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs, when considering Plaintiff’s medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and other damages.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1\u20132.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County Superior Court, Somerville Division, pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1–2, because the events giving rise to this action occurred in Somerville, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and Defendant transacts business and maintains a regular place of business there.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7\u00a7 3(a), 3(d)..proposition: Personal jurisdiction over Defendant is proper because Defendant conducts business in Massachusetts, owns/operates the Premises in Somerville, and the tortious conduct alleged herein occurred within the Commonwealth.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land who invites members of the public onto the premises for business purposes owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn of or remedy dangers that the possessor knows or reasonably should know about.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a short concurring passage that criticizes continued reliance on entrant-status categories (trespasser/licensee/invitee) and does not itself articulate or adopt a specific duty rule for business invitees. While the full Mounsey majority opinion is known for broadening landowner duties, this quoted portion neither states nor clearly affirms the specific proposition about a duty to exercise reasonable care and warn/remedy known dangers to business invitees. On the basis of the text provided, the case excerpt does not clearly support the claimed proposition.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: “The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a ‘licensee’ rather than an ‘invitee,’ or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … The very effort at dry classification and differentation puts the emphasis at the wrong places.”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land who invites members of the public onto the premises for business purposes owes a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain the premises in a reasonably safe condition, and to warn of or remedy dangers that the possessor knows or reasonably should know about.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes, as part of its doctrinal background and its new holding, the Massachusetts premises-liability rule that a property owner (including a business open to the public) owes lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition and to repair, remove, or warn of dangers the owner knows or should know about. The court then applies that same general duty to hazards arising from snow and ice. This squarely matches the proposition about a possessor of land inviting the public for business purposes owing a duty of reasonable care to maintain safe premises and address known or reasonably knowable dangers.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
“If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.”

“We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards….”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 782–84 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a store owner has a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect customers from foreseeable dangers that arise in areas open to customers, including foreign substances on the floor.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses and reaffirms that, under Massachusetts premises liability law, a store owner must maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition and take steps an ordinarily prudent person would take to prevent accidents, including those involving fruit or vegetable debris on the floor. Sheehan adopts the mode-of-operation approach, which is premised on foreseeability of such hazards in self-service areas and a duty to take reasonable precautions commensurate with those risks. This directly supports the proposition that store owners must protect customers from foreseeable dangers, including foreign substances on the floor in customer areas.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt: “Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’… In particular, as is the case here, fruit and vegetable debris presents an obvious risk of injury to a customer… Thus…the trier of fact must determine whether the owner could reasonably foresee…a foreseeable risk… and whether the owner exercised reasonable care in maintaining the premise in a safe condition commensurate with these foreseeable risks.”

*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.raw_text: *Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2d 515, 517–18 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law)
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that a store owner has a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect customers from foreseeable dangers that arise in areas open to customers, including foreign substances on the floor.
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether Massachusetts law allows recovery of reputation damages in an ordinary negligence case arising from an airplane accident at Logan Airport. It does not address premises liability, store owners, duties to customers, foreign substances on floors, or any analogous duty to protect invitees from conditions on property. Nothing in the reasoning or holding discusses or establishes the general duty proposition claimed, so the case does not support that statement of Massachusetts law.
*Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 905 F.2.relevant_excerpt: "In any negligence cause of action, there are four elements on which plaintiffs must adduce adequate evidence to prevail. Plaintiffs must show: (1) a legal duty owed by defendant to plaintiff; (2) a breach of that duty; (3) proximate or legal cause; and (4) actual damage or injury." (905 F.2d at 535). (This passage is generic and does not concern store owners or foreign substances on floors.)

*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 363 Mass. 165, 166–68 (1973)
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.proposition: Even if Defendant lacked actual knowledge, the presence of cart tracks through the puddle shows that the condition existed for a sufficient length of time that, in the exercise of reasonable care, Defendant should have discovered and remedied it, thereby giving rise to constructive notice under Massachusetts law.
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.support_reasoning: The proposition posits that circumstantial evidence like cart tracks through a puddle can establish that a condition existed long enough to give constructive notice under Massachusetts law. Oliveri does discuss constructive notice and the time element, but it ultimately holds that circumstantial evidence about the condition of an unknown substance (its stickiness/adherence) was insufficient to show it existed long enough. The opinion therefore constrains, rather than supports, using such indirect condition evidence alone to infer constructive notice, and does not endorse the specific cart‑tracks rationale stated in the proposition.
*Oliveri v. Mass. Bay Transp. Auth.*, 36.relevant_excerpt: “The issue presented is whether the evidence is sufficient to permit a jury to infer that the substance had been on the step long enough so that in the exercise of reasonable care the defendant should have discovered and removed it… Where the nature of the substance is not known and there is no way to know if it turns black with time, or where the effect of time is not obvious or remains unproved, no inference is warranted that the substance has been on the ground or floor long enough to have been seen and removed… There is nothing to distinguish this case from the great majority of cases in which we have held that directed verdicts were required.”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.proposition: Under Massachusetts negligence law, Defendant’s duty and breach are measured by the standard of ordinary care and foreseeability.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.support_reasoning: The court expressly articulates Massachusetts negligence elements and ties duty to reasonable care and foreseeability of harm. It states that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care when the risk of harm is recognizable or foreseeable, and that duty is owed to all persons foreseeably endangered by the conduct. The opinion then applies this ordinary-care/foreseeability framework to determine both the existence and scope of the defendant’s duty in this negligent storage case.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u201.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care… We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’… A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor… Consequently… ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’”

*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.proposition: Under Massachusetts negligence law, Defendant’s duty and breach are measured by the standard of ordinary care and foreseeability.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly describes Massachusetts negligence as requiring proof of a duty of reasonable care and later explains that liability is limited to harms within the scope of foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct. It ties causation and scope of liability to whether the injury was a foreseeable result of the alleged negligence, thereby grounding duty/breach and causation in ordinary care and foreseeability. Thus it directly supports the proposition about the ordinary care and foreseeability standard in Massachusetts negligence law.
*Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.*, 454 M.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on his negligence claims, Leavitt must prove that the hospital owed him a duty of reasonable care, that the hospital committed a breach of that duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of duty and the damage.… Liability for conduct obtains only where the conduct is both a cause in fact of the injury and where the resulting injury is within the scope of the foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct.… Negligence limits the requirement of reasonable care to those risks that are foreseeable.”

*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.proposition: Causation and compensable damages are core elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.support_reasoning: The court expressly describes what plaintiffs must prove to prevail on their negligence claims, listing breach of duty, actual loss, and causation, and then reiterates that causation is an essential element. This directly supports the proposition that causation and compensable damages (actual loss) are core elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law.
*Glidden v. Maglio*, 430 Mass. 694, 696\.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

*Wells v. Town of Concord*, 8 Mass. App..raw_text: *Wells v. Town of Concord*, 8 Mass. App. Ct. 317, 319–20 (1979)
*Wells v. Town of Concord*, 8 Mass. App..proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for all injuries and losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including, but not limited to: past and future medical expenses, lost wages and diminished earning capacity, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.
*Wells v. Town of Concord*, 8 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion in Wells v. Town of Concord concerns double jeopardy and whether there was ‘manifest necessity’ for declaring a mistrial, not the scope of compensatory damages in a negligence or personal injury action. It neither discusses civil damages nor identifies categories such as medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, or loss of enjoyment of life. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about recoverable compensatory damages.
*Wells v. Town of Concord*, 8 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: "We do not conceive of circumstances in which a judge’s vacation plans would constitute 'manifest necessity’ and justify subjecting a defendant to the expense and strain of another trial."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B, 85.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover compensatory damages for all injuries and losses proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including, but not limited to: past and future medical expenses, lost wages and diminished earning capacity, pain and suffering, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment of life.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 6B and 6C.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 231, §§ 6B and 6C, Plaintiff is also entitled to prejudgment interest on any judgment entered in her favor from the date of commencement of this action.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 60.proposition: Plaintiff asserts her right to a trial by jury under the Massachusetts Constitution and G.L. c. 231, § 60.

G.L. c. 261.proposition: An award of costs of this action as permitted by law, including but not limited to filing fees and other allowable costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261;
